report_title: Executive Search Recruiters in the US
executive_summary: The executive search recruiting industry continues to benefit from strong corporate profit growth and an ever-growing terrain of businesses in need of their services. Since executive recruiters provide services across all sectors, demand for their work is affected by the broader economy. The pandemic resulted in high unemployment, hindering operators significantly. Over the past five years, revenue grew at a CAGR of 2.3% to an estimated $10.5 billion in 2024. Profit is expected to reach 9.3% of revenue in 2024.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: The labor market continues to affect revenue
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Historically, revenue has exhibited a high correlation with employment rates. The unemployment rate has increased over the past five years, hindering the industry. In 2020, the pandemic caused the unemployment rate to jump significantly, resulting in a substantial decline in revenue.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Operators Encounter Corporate Expansion and Restructuring
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: The number of businesses grew steadily, but stagnation in 2020 and 2021 negatively impacted executive search recruiters' core market base. The business sentiment index underwent volatility as rising interest rates harmed business sentiment nationally.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Competition from Internal Departments Hinders Operators
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Operators contended with competition from in-house hiring, staffing agencies and online networking sites. Large businesses relied on in-house recruiting or promoting from within for middle-management positions. Online databases enabled businesses to search for candidates more effectively.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Mixed Economic Conditions are Expected to Impact Recruiter Performance
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Anticipated economic growth will positively impact revenue, but concerns over a potential recession and Fed tightening monetary policy to combat inflation could curtail large-scale recruitment as companies look to shrink expenditures.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Operators are Expected to Continue Encountering Intensified Competition
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Businesses will likely continue using internal staff and online networks for recruitment, reducing demand for services. Smaller companies will opt to recruit management from within rather than seek outside candidates.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Increased Globalization is Expected to Increase Demand from Operators
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Larger companies planning to branch into other countries will continue to seek services of executive search firms with expertise in placing competent executives abroad. Increased globalization will give larger operators a competitive advantage.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Expansion of Artificial Intelligence (AI) May Bolster Recruitment Efficiency
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: AI could allow faster processing of applicant data and insights into skillsets, boosting operational efficiency for recruiters. AI can also help root out systemic bias when analyzing candidates.

industry_definition: This industry provides executive search, recruitment and placement services for clients with specific executive and senior management requirements. Industry firms develop a search strategy and position specification based on the client's culture and needs. Operators research, identify, screen and interview candidates; verify candidate qualifications; and assist in final offer negotiations and the assimilation of the selected candidate.
key_trends: Firms seek to specialize in niche areas and gather a better understanding of a specific sector.
Quality operators also benefit the most in the overall market.
Operators encounter competition from in-house human resource departments. Companies that find hiring executives on their own more efficient represent external competition for the industry.

Inflation uncertainty continues to pose notable economic risks to recruitment. If inflation continues to rise, the Federal Reserve will continue to raise interest rates, which will cause an economic slowdown, hindering recruitment demand.
Larger operators make strategic acquisitions to expand their market share. Acquisitions enable operators to service companies in various industries and geographic regions.
Large operators develop their own software for in-house use. This software enables large operators in the industry to gain an advantage over small companies.
A core requirement for recruiters is that they must acquire a license. However, licensing requirements vary between local and state governments.
Operators benefit from being members of industry-specific associations. Associations enable operators to network, attend conferences and research summits.
Operators encountered downward pressure on profit because of the pandemic. Operators specializing in travel and food service were mainly hindered the most.

Wages have jumped despite challenging economic conditions during the pandemic. Companies have sought to hire executives or mid-management employees when the company is struggling to help improve conditions.

market_segmentation.segment_description: This encompassing market includes aviation, energy, automotive, chemical, packaging and heavy manufacturing industries. Sector-wide innovation, a modest recovery in domestic industrial production levels in the latter part of the period and the increasing complexity of global supply chains have boosted demand for highly capable executives worldwide to oversee new and expanding existing projects.

This market includes investment banking, asset management, consumer and commercial banking, insurance, accounting and real estate. Operators in the financial sector use executive search recruiters to source and attract the best talent, assist in retaining valuable employees and build a high-performance culture.

This market segment includes all retail and wholesaling establishments and manufacturers of nondurable goods, including foods and personal care items. The retail and consumer packaged goods (CPG) markets are vital to the US economy. Businesses that dominate the domestic market, like Nestle SA or Walmart, also have a major presence abroad. Increased globalization within this sector has increased the need for capable executives overseeing the company's operations across a wide range of geographic regions.

products_and_services.product_description: Retained executive search services for C-level and board candidates continues to make up the most popular and in-demand service. Executive recruitment firms typically focus on filling positions with more than $250,000 annual compensation. Such positions usually comprise senior executive, chief executive (CEO, CFO, CIO), board-level appointees and mid-

Contingency search services focus on recruiting and placing mid-tier management candidates into positions with annual compensation below the typical "executive" base salary range of $250,000 but typically higher than $100,000. Fees for these services are commonly charged on a contingency basis, where an operator is compensated only after a position has been successfully filled. Referrals for these services are often the result of an executive recruitment firm having done a previous, more high-profile search and hiring for a corporate client.

In addition to finding and placing job candidates, executive search recruiters offer various advisory and consulting services related to corporate leadership and succession strategies. These services can extend to coaching new executives and meeting with a company's board to develop a transitional organizational or structural change strategy.

demand_determinants.determinant_description: Corporate profit is the profit earned across all industries in the United States. When profit is high, businesses have a greater ability to invest in new practices or services, like using recruitment agencies. However, businesses may also increase their search for new senior management while profit is low to resuscitate profitability. Overall, increased corporate profit typically translates into higher revenue and symbolizes strong economic conditions.

business_locations.location_description: The Southeast region has the highest share of industry establishments at 37.5% despite having only 23.1% of the US population. This indicates a high business concentration in the Southeast region.
The Mid-Atlantic contains much more establishments than its share of US population because of the high concentration of major businesses headquartered in the region.

The West region contains the third-highest share of establishments. The high concentration of establishments is because of key metropolitan areas located in California, including Los Angeles and San Francisco.

regulations_points.regulation_description: Executive search recruiters face little regulatory oversight. The primary requirement for conducting business is acquiring a license, but specific requirements vary between local and state governments. At times, the varied legislation can present hurdles to executive search recruiters. For example, operators may experience difficulty conducting business with clients in other states because policies under contractual law may not be upheld for out-of-state companies.

More information is published online and in electronic databases, including information about individuals. Since it is part of executive recruiters' business to create and manage a database of prospective candidates, the industry is likely to be affected by any data privacy laws that are enacted. Operators may also be subject to extensive non-disclosure and confidentiality regulations, particularly if the operator focuses on recruiting higher-tier executive or board member candidates.

In 2020, as the pandemic damaged the economy, the US government passed additional regulations to aid businesses and slow the spread of the virus. Although no direct legislation on executive search recruiters was passed, operators had to comply with broad regulations. This included the Families First Coronavirus Response Act, which required employers to provide employees with paid sick leave or expanded family and medical leave for pandemic-related reasons.

The Equal Employment Opportunity (EEO) guidance was established to protect against potential discrimination and ensure all potential candidates are treated fairly and equitably during the hiring process. The law is administered via the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission (EEOC), and executive search recruiters must adhere to the guidance set by the commission prior to searching for a candidate.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Purchases Lag as the Pandemic Hindered Demand for Recruiters' Services
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Purchase costs continue to be affected by heightened inflationary pressures that have exacerbated costs for executive search recruiters. Purchases primarily include administrative office supplies, such as paper, desks, laptops and chairs. Historically, purchase costs have fluctuated between 15.0% and 18.0%, driven partly by changes in demand. In recent years, the effects of inflation have been noteworthy, as the costs of these supplies continues to accelerate.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Profit Slumps as Overarching Effects of High Inflation and Interest Rates Take Their Toll
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Profit, measured as earnings before interest and taxes, has slumped in recent years due to the effects of high inflation and rising interest rates. Profit for executive search firms is typically higher than for traditional staffing firms. The search for highly skilled and capable employees that can fill executive and senior management positions is accompanied by higher fees. Fees can account for over one-third of the successful candidate's salary in the first year, plus bonuses depending on the company's performance following the placement.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Wages Jump as Highly Skilled Consultants with Experience in Senior Management are Crucial
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Wage expenses remain the largest and most consistent expenditure for operators. Labor costs are significant, including commissions paid to recruitment professionals for finding a successful candidate and future payments based on success.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: Recruiters rely on direct human input and experience for tasks. Operators require extensive research, scheduling, coordinating and interviewing for tasks.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: TECHNOLOGICAL ENHANCEMENT IMPROVES WORKFLOW EFFICIENCY AND PROVIDES A COMPETITIVE EDGE
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Large operators seek to gain an advantage by developing their software programs. Clients and operators can use these internal software programs, which enable information sharing. These internally developed software programs can also be customized to better support operators. Specialized information technology can give companies an edge in the industry.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: Operators Expanding Services Offered to Diversify Their Portfolios
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Operators seek to expand service offerings. Operators offer various and additional advisory and consulting services. Advisory and consulting services complement traditional industry services.

volatility_points.volatility_title: Operators Encounter Cyclical Performance, but Were Affected by the Pandemic
volatility_points.volatility_description: Executive search recruiters continue to be prone to economic volatility. Over the past five years, revenue has undergone significant fluctuations, mostly in 2020 during the pandemic and 2021 as economic conditions rebounded.

volatility_points.volatility_title: Economic Factors and Mergers and Acquisitions Fuel Revenue Volatility
volatility_points.volatility_description: Demand for executive recruiting services fluctuates based on the national unemployment rate, corporate profit levels and broader factors like overall management restructuring activity and trends in globalization and outsourcing.

FAQs.question: What regulations did executive search recruiters have to comply with during the COVID-19 pandemic?
FAQs.answer: Executive search recruiters had to comply with broad regulations like the Families First Coronavirus Response Act, which required employers to provide employees with paid sick leave or expanded family and medical leave for pandemic-related reasons.

FAQs.question: What is the Equal Employment Opportunity (EEO) guidance and how does it apply to executive search recruiters?
FAQs.answer: The Equal Employment Opportunity (EEO) guidance was established to protect against potential discrimination and ensure all potential candidates are treated fairly and equitably during the hiring process.

FAQs.question: What assistance is available for the executive search industry?
FAQs.answer: The level of industry assistance is described as low and steady.

FAQs.question: What are the benefits of membership in relevant industry associations for executive search firms?
FAQs.answer: Membership in associations like the Association of Executive Search Consultants (AESC) enables firms to feature the AESC logo, assuring clients of professional standards.

FAQs.question: Do executive search firms specialize or bundle their services?
FAQs.answer: Executive search firms usually specialize in placing executives in a specific sector.

FAQs.question: Is business growth vital for executive search firms?
FAQs.answer: As businesses undertake new operations, they need executives to head them, leading to increased demand for executive searches.

FAQs.question: Do executive search firms target niche markets or broad ranges?
FAQs.answer: Most executive search firms provide their services in a specific sector based on an in-depth understanding of the talents required to be a successful executive.

FAQs.question: Is maintaining repeat customers important for executive search firms?
FAQs.answer: While companies only demand executive search services when they have an open position, providing quality candidates helps secure future business.

FAQs.question: Do executive search firms use mobile apps to reduce costs and improve efficiency?
FAQs.answer: Executive search firms have used mobile applications and analytic tools to provide businesses with quality executives that fit their client's unique needs.

FAQs.question: Are web technologies like online storage and video conferencing hurting executive search businesses?
FAQs.answer: Web-based tools have helped executive search firms conduct in-depth analysis of candidates for executive positions.

FAQs.question: Are executive search firms responsible for safeguarding customer information?
FAQs.answer: Since executive search firms are dealing with candidates' business profiles, assuring they keep candidates' information private is of the utmost importance.
